title: Safety by Design Index
meta_description: An index for classifying how effectively safety has been designed into a device. Rate devices from 0 (no protection) to 5 (inherently safe).
og_description: An index for classifying how effectively safety has been designed into a device. Like IP ratings, but for safety.
subtitle: A common language for discussing device safety and encouraging safer-by-design development.
intro_p1: How safe is a device, really? And how much does it depend on the person using it? This framework builds on the Hierarchy of Controls to give a clear answer. Think of it like IP ratings, but for how well a device protects its users.
intro_p2: Take the Petzl GriGri, a climbing device designed to grip the rope automatically when a climber falls. Many assume it will lock automatically, but catastrophic failures can occur when operators overestimate a device's safety level.
how_to_use: Rate the device based on its primary hazard under normal operating conditions. Focus on what the device does to protect the operator, not edge cases or deliberate tampering.

levels.name: No Protection
levels.description: The device offers no protective features. The hazard is fully exposed and no skill or technique can make it safe.
examples: A vintage bench grinder with no wheel guards, no eye shields, and no spark arrestors. The spinning abrasive wheel is fully exposed during operation.
An open fire pit. The flames and heat are exposed during use.

levels.name: Safe Only With Correct Use
levels.description: The device provides no engineering controls to help the operator. Safety relies entirely on user skill, procedures and PPE.
levels.table_description: No engineering controls. Safety depends on the operator.
examples: A basic chainsaw. Safety depends entirely on operator technique, stance, and PPE (chaps, helmet, gloves).
A tube-style belay device. The device has no automatic braking. Safety depends entirely on the belayer maintaining proper grip and technique.

levels.name: Safety Encouraged
levels.description: The device provides cues, markings or warnings to encourage correct behaviour, but does not block unsafe use.
levels.table_description: Cues and warnings, but no enforcement.
examples: An extension ladder with angle indicators, "this side up" labels, and anti-slip feet. These cues guide correct setup, but nothing prevents the operator from ignoring them.
A circular saw with blade guard markings and a safety sticker. The warnings are visible, but nothing prevents the operator from removing the guard.

levels.name: Safety Assisted
levels.description: The device has built-in features that reduce risk automatically, but incorrect technique or accidental misuse can still result in harm.
levels.table_description: Automatic protection, but incorrect technique or misuse can still cause harm.
examples: A power drill with electronic brake, torque limiter, and insulated casing. These features reduce injury risk, but the operator can still slip or drill into something they shouldn't.
A car with seatbelts and airbags. The safety systems help significantly in a crash, but reckless driving can still cause serious harm.
An assisted-braking belay device, whether passive or active. The device helps catch a fall automatically, but incorrect technique can still cause the rope to slip through.

levels.name: Fail-Safe
levels.description: The device forces a safe state that cannot be overridden by the operator. No amount of incorrect technique, inattention, or misuse can bypass the protection during normal operation.
levels.table_description: Enforced safe state. Cannot be overridden by operator.
examples: A microwave oven with redundant door interlocks. The magnetron physically cannot energise unless all switches confirm the door is sealed. The operator cannot run the microwave with the door open.
A lift with door interlocks and slack-rope brakes. The car cannot move unless the doors are closed, and it will stop automatically if the cable fails.
A climbing gym auto-belay. The device automatically takes up slack and arrests falls mechanically. The climber cannot override the braking system during normal use.

levels.name: Inherently Safe
levels.description: The danger is designed out entirely. The device simply cannot cause serious harm through normal use.
levels.table_description: Hazard designed out. Cannot cause serious harm.
examples: A plastic letter opener instead of a metal blade. It can open envelopes but cannot cut skin.
A battery-powered desk fan instead of a mains-powered one. The low voltage cannot deliver a dangerous shock.
